tema1.question: In a computer system, what is the interface that defines a standard for binary portability across operating systems (i.e., system call interface), allowing programs to be executed in different operating systems that implement it?
What mode does the operating system run in to be able to execute privileged CPU instructions and access all memory areas?

In a time-sharing operating system, what is the name of the technique in which a system clock generates interrupts at a constant rate to let the operating system gain control of the CPU and decide which user to assign the CPU to next?
What is the name of the first program that is run by a computer after the BIOS (Basic Input/Output System) is executed to check the hardware?
What is an operating system?

answers.answer: A collection of programs that manages hardware resources
A system service provider to the application programs
An interface between the hardware and application programs

tema1.question: To access the services of an operating system, the interface is provided by...
Which one of the following statements is NOT true?

answers.answer: The kernel is the program that constitutes the central core of the operating system
The kernel is the first part of an operating system to load into memory during booting
The kernel is made of various modules which can be loaded dynamically when running the operating system
The kernel remains in the memory during the entire computer session

tema1.question: What is the main function of the CLI (Command Line Interface)?

answers.answer: To get and execute the next user-specified command
To provide the interface between the API and application program
To handle the files in operating system

tema1.question: Operating systems that only allow the execution of one program simultaneously are called...
What happens when the processor executes an instruction that divides by 0?
In a computer system with a single CPU, which statement is true?

answers.answer: Concurrency cannot be achieved in the execution of processes
Concurrency can be achieved by taking advantage of the moments when processes are not using the processor to execute other processes that are ready to do so
Concurrency is obtained by executing processes simultaneously on the same processor

tema1.question: In a computer system with more than one CPU, which statement is true?

answers.answer: No type of concurrency can be achieved
It can be made to appear to the user that there are many processes running at the same time, but in reality they are alternating between them
Concurrency is achieved by running the processes simultaneously on different processors

tema1.question: In a computer system with more than one CPU, which statement is TRUE?

answers.answer: Processes cannot be executed simultaneously on different processors
The maximum concurrency that can be achieved is equal to the number of CPUs
There will only be one process in real simultaneous execution, but you can take advantage of the moments when a process is waiting to execute another

tema1.question: A multiprocessor system is one that:

answers.answer: Has two or more processing units in the system
Has two or more memory units in the system
Has two or more disk drives in the system

tema1.question: Operating systems that can only execute one program at a time are called:
In a computer system that has a single CPU and runs a multi-programmed operating system, which of the following sentences is TRUE?

answers.answer: Only a single program can be loaded in the main memory at any given time
Multiple programs can be loaded in the main memory at the same time, but only a single process is allowed to execute at any given time
Multiple programs can be loaded in main memory at the same time, and multiple processes are allowed to execute at any given time
Multiple programs can be loaded in the main memory at the same time, but only one process can be in the ready queue at any given time

tema1.question: The objective of a multi-programmed operating system is:

answers.answer: To keep the I/O devices busy as much of the time as possible
To minimize overall system memory usage
To keep the CPU busy as little time as possible
All of the above are false

tema1.question: In a computer system with two levels of execution, when we are executing code as the operating system the CPU is running in:
In a computer system, what elements connect the processor, main memory, and I/O devices together?
In which stage does the processor retrieve an instruction from the main memory (i.e., RAM)?
What is the primary purpose of using interrupts in a computer system?

answers.answer: To handle external events without stopping normal program execution

tema1.question: Which is NOT a key function of an operating system?

answers.answer: Enabling multiple processes to run concurrently
Facilitating communication between hardware and software

tema1.question: What was the primary goal of early batch operating systems?
Which issue arises due to the introduction of computers with multiple processors in the design of operating systems?
What is the primary difference between a shell script and an executable file in UNIX?

answers.answer: Executable files have extensions, while shell scripts do not
Shell scripts run in user mode, while executables run in kernel mode
Shell scripts are interpreted, while executables are compiled
Executables use more memory than shell scripts

tema1.question: In a computer system, which mechanism is used to protect user processes from unauthorized access by other processes?
What is the primary purpose of the hardware timer interrupt when designing an operating system?
Which CPU mode allows accessing hardware resources directly and executing system calls?
What is the primary difference between a monolithic kernel and a microkernel?

answers.answer: Monolithic kernels run faster than microkernels
Monolithic kernels are easier to maintain than microkernels
Monolithic kernels handle I/O requests asynchronously, while microkernels handle them synchronously
Monolithic kernels have a single and large address space, while microkernels have multiple and smaller address spaces

tema1.question: What of the following is NOT a benefit of using dynamic linking and loading over static linking?

answers.answer: It allows shared libraries to be updated without recompiling the application

tema1.question: What is the primary difference between signals and system calls in UNIX-like operating systems?

answers.answer: Signals are generated by the kernel, while system calls are initiated by user programs
System calls are synchronous, while signals are asynchronous
System calls require a context switch, while signals do not

tema1.question: What is the term for the smallest unit of execution within an operating system?
What is the role of a file system in an operating system?

answers.answer: To manage storage and retrieval of data on devices

tema1.question: What is the primary function of a disk scheduler in an operating system?
Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of a real-time operating system?
What is a context switch in an operating system?

answers.answer: The process of loading a program into memory
The process of saving and restoring the state of a CPU
The execution of a single instruction

tema1.question: What is the primary goal of a batch operating system?

answers.answer: To provide immediate response for interactive tasks
To maximize CPU utilization by processing jobs in groups

tema1.question: What type of operating system is designed for applications that require high concurrency and low latency?
What type of operating system is DOS (Disk Operating System) introduced by Microsoft to run in the first PCs (Personal Computers)?
What is the main characteristic of a time-sharing operating system?

answers.answer: Multiple users share CPU resources simultaneously
Only one user can access the system at a time

tema2.question: What are the main objectives of an operating system scheduler?

answers.answer: Maximize the use of the system processor

tema2.question: What is the primary function of a process scheduler?
Which of the statements about process scheduling is TRUE?

answers.answer: If a process is suspended, it does not need a PCB
It is not possible to suspend processes that are in blocked state
A running process must go through each and every stage of the life cycle before it finishes
All of the above statements are false

tema2.question: What is the role of a dispatcher in process scheduling?

answers.answer: To handle interrupts and system calls
To manage the allocation of memory to processes
To create new processes and allocate resources to them
To select a process from the ready queue and load it onto the CPU for execution

tema2.question: What element of the operating system is responsible to perform the context switch between the process that is currently being executed in the CPU and the process from the ready queue that the operating system has decided to execute next?
What is meant by 'context switching' in the context of process scheduling?

answers.answer: The allocation of memory to a new process
The handling of an interrupt by the operating system
The process of saving the state of one running process and loading the state of another process for execution

tema2.question: What is the relationship between the scheduler and the dispatcher in process scheduling?

answers.answer: The dispatcher handles interrupts, while the scheduler manages process priorities
The scheduler selects processes for execution, while the dispatcher loads them onto the CPU
The dispatcher selects processes for execution, while the scheduler manages their memory allocation
The scheduler and dispatcher are interchangeable terms with no distinct roles

tema2.question: Why is context switching considered an overhead in operating systems?

answers.answer: It complicates the implementation of scheduling algorithms, making them less efficient
It increases the memory footprint of each process due to storing additional state information
It requires time and resources to save and restore the states of processes, slowing down execution

tema2.question: What is a key difference between preemptive and non-preemptive scheduling algorithms?

answers.answer: Preemptive schedulers are more complex to implement than non-preemptive schedulers
Preemptive scheduling is only used in real-time systems, while non-preemptive scheduling is suitable for general-purpose operating systems
Preemptive schedulers can interrupt running processes, while non-preemptive schedulers only switch when a process voluntarily relinquishes the CPU

tema2.question: In what scenarios would a context switch be necessary?

answers.answer: When a new process is created by the operating system
When a process completes execution and finishes
When a process makes a system call and has to wait for the operating system to load the resources

tema2.question: Which of these factors does NOT directly influence the decision-making process of a process scheduler?

answers.answer: The current state of each process (running, ready, blocked)
The physical layout of memory in the computer system

tema2.question: What is the main purpose of a Gantt Chart in process scheduling?

answers.answer: To visually represent the execution timeline of processes
To determine the optimal scheduling algorithm

tema2.question: What is a convoy effect in process scheduling?

answers.answer: When a process exceeds its allocated time quantum
When multiple processes are waiting for the same resource
When processes continuously switch between ready and running states
When a slow process delays other processes behind it in a queue

tema2.question: What does the 'Ready Queue' represent in process scheduling?

answers.answer: The set of active processes currently running on different CPU cores
A list of blocked processes waiting for resources to become available
A collection of processes that are waiting to be executed by the CPU

tema2.question: The system scheduler that is responsible for controlling the degree of multiprogramming of the system (i.e., the number of processes that can be running in the system) is called:
In short-term and non-preemptive scheduling algorithms, which of the following sentences is TRUE:

answers.answer: Context switching occurs whenever the system quantum ends
Context switching occurs only when the process terminates
Context switching occurs only when the process ends its CPU streak and enters an I/O streak

tema2.question: When we have a processor scheduler that seeks to maximize system availability, what does it refer to?

answers.answer: Priority processes will always be executed
Non-priority processes will never be executed
No process should wait indefinitely to have the processor

tema2.question: Regarding the mid-term scheduler, which of the following statements is TRUE?

answers.answer: It handles processes that are in the ready queue to move them to execution
It handles processes suspended in the main memory (i.e., RAM) to move them to the ready queue
It handles processes suspended in secondary memory (i.e., disk) to move them to ready queue

tema2.question: In the five-state process model, when a running process requests a system resource or when an I/O operation requires the process to wait, to which state does the process transition to?
Regarding process scheduling, which of the following statements is TRUE?

answers.answer: If a process is suspended, it does not need a PCB
It is not possible to suspend processes that are in blocked state
A running process must go through each and every stage of the life cycle before it finishes
All of the above statements are false

tema2.question: In what state is a process that is waiting for an input/output operation (i.e., reading a file from disk)?
When a process terminates executing before its parent process does and is waiting for the parent to execute, we say that it is a...
If we have a process in Ready state, if we query its status after a quantum of execution time, the process can be in which of the following states?
In the five-state process model, when a running process requests a system resource or requires to wait for an I/O operation, to which state does it transition to?

In the six-state process model, when a process suspended in the secondary memory (i.e., the process is swapped to disk) is activated (i.e., an event occurs that allows the process to execute), to which state does the process transition to?
What is the purpose of a Process Control Block (PCB)?

answers.answer: To manage the allocation of CPU time to processes
To store all the information associated with a process, such as its state, priority, and memory allocation
To perform system calls on behalf of processes

tema2.question: What is a potential benefit of storing process state information in a PCB (Process Control Block)?

answers.answer: Reduces the need for memory management
Simplifies the implementation of scheduling algorithms
Guarantees fairness among all running processes
Enables efficient suspension and resumption of processes, allowing for multitasking

tema2.question: What information does the PCB (Process Control Block) contain?
What information is typically included in the 'process state' field within a PCB (Process Control Block)?

answers.answer: The amount of CPU time allocated to the process
The priority level of the process
Whether the process is running, ready, blocked, or terminated
The size of the process’s memory allocation

tema2.question: Which of the following information is typically NOT stored within a Process Control Block (PCB)?

answers.answer: State of the process (i.e., running, ready, blocked)
A pointer to the program image

tema2.question: Why might a PCB include information about a process’s parent?

answers.answer: To track the lineage of all processes in the system for debugging purposes
To facilitate process hierarchies and resource management between related processes
To prevent deadlocks by ensuring parent processes always terminate before their children
To allow communication between parent and child processes using shared memory

tema2.question: The operating system scheduler that allocates processor time among the different processes of the operating system in quantums of equal duration is called:
Which scheduling algorithm favors shorter jobs by giving them priority?
Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of a preemptive scheduling algorithm?

answers.answer: Always results in shorter average waiting times
Used when real-time responsiveness is crucial

tema2.question: What problem can arise with the Priority Scheduling (PS) algorithm if not handled carefully?
In a multilevel queue scheduling system, what typically determines the priority level of a process?

answers.answer: Process characteristics like type or importance
The time spent waiting in the ready queue

tema2.question: What is a potential disadvantage of using a very small time quantum in Round Robin (RR) scheduling?
Which non-preemptive scheduling algorithm is known for its simplicity and fairness, but may lead to longer average waiting times?
Which preemptive scheduling algorithm is particularly well-suited for real-time systems where meeting deadlines is crucial?
What is the main advantage of multi-level queue scheduling over single-level queue scheduling?

answers.answer: It guarantees fairness for all processes
It simplifies the implementation of scheduling algorithms
It allows for better differentiation and prioritization of processes based on their characteristics

tema2.question: Which of the following is a potential drawback of using a SJF (Shortest Job First) scheduling algorithm?

answers.answer: It can lead to starvation of longer jobs
It does not prioritize important tasks
It is computationally expensive to implement
It requires knowledge of the future CPU burst times of processes, which may not be readily available

tema2.question: Which scheduling algorithm is considered non-preemptive?
Which scheduling algorithm is generally considered fairer to all processes, even if it doesn’t optimize for shortest average waiting times?
What is a major disadvantage of the First Come, First Served (FCFS) scheduling algorithm?

answers.answer: It does not prioritize important tasks
It requires knowledge of future CPU burst times
It can lead to long average waiting times, especially if a long process arrives early

tema2.question: Which scheduling algorithm is more susceptible to the 'convoy effect', where a slow process delays others behind it?
How does the time quantum in Round Robin scheduling affect process performance?

answers.answer: A very large time quantum approaches FCFS behavior
A very small time quantum increases context switching overhead but can improve responsiveness
The time quantum has no impact on process performance
A fixed time quantum always leads to optimal CPU utilization

tema2.question: What is a benefit of using SJF (Shortest Job First) scheduling?

answers.answer: It can minimize average waiting times for processes
It guarantees fairness for all processes

tema2.question: What is a potential drawback of using Priority Scheduling (PS) if not carefully implemented?
When might a multi-level queue scheduling approach be beneficial?

answers.answer: When there are distinct classes of processes with different priorities or resource requirements
When simplicity is the primary concern
When all processes have equal importance
When real-time responsiveness is not critical

tema2.question: Which scheduling algorithm typically results in the highest CPU utilization?

answers.answer: Round Robin (RR) with a large time quantum
Priority Scheduling (PS) with many priority levels

tema2.question: Which of the following scheduling algorithms does not generate starvation to processes?

In which of the following schedulers the return time of the process will only depend on the number of processes that are in the ready queue regardless of their required burst or remaining execution times?
Which of the following scheduling algorithms is preemptive and provides good response times for short processes with minimum overhead?
When an operating system uses a RR (Round Robin) scheduler, which of the following statements is TRUE?

answers.answer: The turnaround time of a process only depends on the service time of that process
The turnaround time of a process only depends on the number of processes running in the system
The turnaround time of a process only depends on the arrival time (when the process was first created)
The turnaround time of a process depends on the combination of all the factors (arrival time, service time and number of processes)

tema2.question: Which scheduling algorithm generally prioritizes minimizing ‘waiting time’, often leading to shorter response times?

answers.answer: Round Robin (RR) with a small time quantum
Priority Scheduling (PS) with high priority for short processes

tema2.question: What performance parameter is defined as ‘the time that a process must wait between it arrives at the system and it finishes executing’?
What is meant by ‘throughput’ in the context of process scheduling?

answers.answer: The number of processes completed per unit of time
The average waiting time for a process in the ready queue
The amount of CPU time allocated to each process
The response time of the system to user requests

tema2.question: Which metric measures ‘the average amount of time a process spends waiting in the ready queue before it is allocated to the CPU’?
How does ‘CPU utilization’ directly relate to process scheduling?

answers.answer: It is a measure of system responsiveness to user requests
It represents the total number of processes completed by the system per unit of time
It indicates the average amount of time a process waits for resources before being executed
It measures the percentage of time the CPU is actively executing instructions, reflecting scheduler efficiency in keeping the CPU busy

tema2.question: Which factor is LEAST likely to directly influence ‘throughput’ in a process scheduling system?

answers.answer: The efficiency of the scheduler in allocating CPU time
The programming language used by the processes
The number of available resources (e.g., memory, I/O devices)

tema2.question: How can 'turnaround time' be minimized when dealing with processes that have varying execution times?

answers.answer: Maximizing CPU utilization by keeping the CPU constantly busy
Always using a First-Come, First-Served (FCFS) scheduling approach
Reducing context switching overhead through efficient dispatcher implementation
By prioritizing shorter processes using algorithms like Shortest Job First (SJF)

tema2.question: What is a potential drawback of solely focusing on minimizing 'response time' as a primary performance metric?

answers.answer: It always guarantees the highest possible throughput for the system
It is not relevant in interactive systems requiring quick responses
It might lead to starvation of longer processes, causing them to experience significant delays

tema2.question: What is the most important performance parameter in an operating system that is used in a real-time application (i.e., the ECU <Electronic Control Unit> of a car)?

answers.answer: Processor utilization (i.e., the utilization of the CPU is maximized)
Allocation fairness (i.e., all processes in the system receive the same amount of computational resources)
Execution determinism (each process takes the same amount of time to complete regardless of the system state)
Throughput maximization (i.e., the number of processes that are completed by the system per unit of time)

tema2.question: What value does the fork() system call return when it succeeds and returns execution to the child process?
What value does the fork() system call return when it succeeds and returns execution to the parent process?

answers.answer: A positive integer representing the child's PID

tema2.question: To get the process identifier of the child process that was just created in a fork() system call, a parent process can use the system call:
To get the process identifier of the parent process, a child process can use the system call:
What does the fork() system call primarily achieve?

answers.answer: Executes a new program with a different set of arguments
Creates a new process, which is an exact copy of the parent process
Modifies the file permissions of a specified file

tema2.question: Which statement about the memory space of a child process after a successful fork() is TRUE?

answers.answer: It is empty and needs to be initialized by the child process
It is completely independent and unrelated to the parent's memory space
It shares the same memory space as the parent process, but with different data modifications
It is a copy of the parent's entire memory space, including open files and other resources

tema2.question: What happens after fork(), before the child process can start executing its own code?

answers.answer: The child process enters an idle state until explicitly woken up by the parent
The child process waits for the parent process to finish before starting its execution
The child process inherits the parent's current program counter and executes the same code

tema2.question: Which system call is responsible for replacing the current process image with a new program?
What happens to the original process image after a successful exec() call?

answers.answer: It remains unchanged, but its execution context is modified
It is completely overwritten by the new program’s code and data
It is removed from memory to free space to create a new process image for the child
It is saved by the operating system and restored when the child process finishes executing

tema2.question: If a program executes exec() without using fork(), which of the following sentences better describes the outcome?

answers.answer: The parent process will still be executed after the new program loaded by exec() finishes executing
The parent process will continue running in parallel with the new process that has been created using exec()
The new program executed by exec() will still be able to access any resources from the parent process
The new program executed by exec() will have a different PID than the parent process to reflect it is a new process

tema2.question: What is the difference between exec() and fork(), in terms of process execution?

answers.answer: fork() creates a new process, while exec() replaces the current process with a new one
fork() executes a new program, while exec() terminates the current process
fork() waits for the child process to finish, while exec() does not
There is no practical difference, both system calls achieve the same result

tema2.question: Which of the following statements about exec() family functions (e.g., execl(), execv()) is FALSE?

answers.answer: They take arguments specifying the path to the new program and its arguments
They modify the current process, replacing it with a new one
They return only if an error occurs during the process of loading and executing the new program
They always create a new child process before replacing the current process

tema2.question: If a process calls fork() followed by an immediate call to exec(), what happens to the parent process that called fork()?

answers.answer: The parent process continues executing normally, creating a new child process and replacing it with another program
The parent process is paused until the child process completes execution of the program loaded by exec()
The parent process terminates as soon as the child process is created
The parent process remains dormant until explicitly awakened using a system call like wait() or sleep()

tema2.question: In the context of fork() system call, which statement is TRUE?

answers.answer: The new process created by fork() will always have the same address space as the parent process
The new process created by fork() will never share the memory space with the parent process
The new process created by fork() may or may not inherit all the resources of the parent process
The new process created by fork() always runs simultaneously with the parent process

tema2.question: What happens to the old (parent) program’s address space after a successful fork() and exec()?

answers.answer: It remains unchanged in both parent and child processes
It is replaced only in the child process
It is replaced in both parent and child processes
It is deleted from both parent and child processes

tema2.question: If a child process is created from another process with a system call to fork(), the created child process will inherit:

answers.answer: The PID of the process (both processes have the same PID)
The file descriptors that the parent process has (both processes can access the same files without reopening them)
The execution time of the process (both processes will take the same CPU time to execute)

tema2.question: We have a child process created with the fork() system call. If the child wants to send some information to the parent, which of the following can be used as a communication mechanism?

answers.answer: A global integer variable of the parent process
A local integer variable of the parent process
A local integer variable of the child process

tema3.question: Which of the following I/O devices use block-oriented data transfers?
In which of the following I/O data transfer modes the operating system uses a busy-waiting strategy to wait until the data transfer operation is complete?
About input and output devices, which statement is TRUE?

answers.answer: A physical device is formed by the peripheral and the software that manages it
Logical devices do not necessarily have to have a physical device associated with them
The window is a logical type device
All of the above statements are true

tema3.question: Which I/O device typically uses character-oriented data transfers?
In which data transfer mode does the operating system actively control the data movement between processes and I/O devices?
What is the main function of a controller in managing an I/O device?

answers.answer: To handle errors and translate data formats
To perform data encryption and decryption
To manage memory allocation and deallocation

tema3.question: What does the acronym DMA stand for in I/O devices?
What is the main advantage of using DMA (Direct Memory Access) for data transfer?

answers.answer: It reduces CPU involvement in data movement
It increases data security during transfers
It provides real-time error correction during data transfers

tema3.question: Consider a disk with an average seek time of 8 ms, rotation speed of 6000 rpm, 512-byte sectors, and 1024 sectors per track. Suppose that we wish to read a file consisting of 256 kbytes (1 kbyte = 1024 bytes). What is the transfer speed (TS, Mbytes/s) if the blocks are stored sequentially?

Consider a disk with an average seek time of 10 ms, rotation speed of 6000 rpm, 1024 bytes per sector, and 1024 sectors per track. Suppose that we wish to read a file that is 1 Mbyte. What is the transfer speed (TS, Mbytes/second) if the blocks are stored sequentially and in the same sector?
What is the disk scheduling policy that minimizes the seek time between consecutive I/O operations regardless of the process priority?
Which disk scheduling policy aims to reduce the total distance traveled by the disk head?
Which disk scheduling policy aims to reduce both seek time and rotational latency by ordering requests based on their expected arrival time?
What is the main difference between the SCAN and C-SCAN disk scheduling policies?

answers.answer: SCAN always starts in the same direction, while C-SCAN alternates directions
SCAN serves requests in both directions simultaneously, while C-SCAN serves them sequentially
SCAN uses a fixed head movement pattern, while C-SCAN adapts to the incoming requests

tema3.question: Which disk scheduling policy always services requests in the order they arrive, without any optimization for seek time or rotational latency?
Which disk scheduling policy is an improvement over the SSTF policy, reducing the chance of starvation for requests that are not at the beginning or end of the disk?
What is the main disadvantage of using the SSTF disk scheduling policy?

answers.answer: It can cause excessive head movement and increased latency for some requests
It requires a complex controller to implement
It is not suitable for systems with high I/O loads

tema3.question: What is the RAID level that provides mirroring between disks, requires an even number of disks, and provides increased read transfer capacity but provides equal read transfer capacity when compared to a single disk?
What is the RAID level that provides block-interleaved distributed parity and requires N+1 disks to operate?
What is the RAID level that provides data striping and error correction capabilities but requires a minimum of 4 disks to operate?
Which RAID level provides striped data without parity or redundancy, offering improved performance but no data protection?
What is the minimum number of disks required for a RAID 10 (or RAID 1+0) configuration?
Which RAID level uses block-level striping with distributed parity and requires a minimum of 3 disks to operate?
In a RAID 5 configuration, where is the parity information stored?

answers.answer: Across all disks in the array on a rotating basis

tema3.question: Which RAID level provides double parity for increased data protection but requires a minimum of 4 disks to operate?

tema4.question: In a UNIX-like filesystem, what is the primary purpose of an i-node?

answers.answer: To keep track of file metadata and disk location information

tema4.question: Where is the file descriptor for an open file stored in a UNIX-like system?

answers.answer: In the process’s file descriptor table
In the kernel’s open file table
In the vnode table of the kernel

tema4.question: Where does the operating system store the 'reference count' variable to indicate the number of processes that are currently pointing to a file that is currently open?

answers.answer: In the file descriptor table of each process
In a file table entry of the open file table
In a vnode table entry of the vnode table
The operating system does not need to store the number of processes that use a file

tema4.question: Where is the information related to the file status flags (i.e., read or write property) and the current file offset stored?

answers.answer: The file descriptor entry in the process table
An entry in the open file table of the kernel
An entry in the vnode table of the kernel

tema4.question: What happens if a file descriptor remains open but the process that opened it terminates without closing it properly?

answers.answer: The file is automatically closed by the kernel
The file remains open indefinitely until reboot
The file is moved to the /tmp directory

tema4.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of the linked allocation method?

answers.answer: Files are stored in contiguous blocks
File blocks are linked using pointers within the file itself
Each block contains a pointer to the next block, stored in a separate directory
Disk space is allocated in large fixed-size chunks called extents

tema4.question: What is the main drawback of the contiguous allocation method?

answers.answer: Inefficient disk space utilization for large files
Fragmentation issues when files are frequently modified

tema4.question: What is the main advantage of using an indexed allocation strategy over contiguous or linked allocation?

answers.answer: More efficient disk space utilization for large files

tema4.question: In which of the following file allocation mechanisms blocks of a file can be distributed across the disk at random, reducing the overall I/O performance of the system?

answers.answer: Indexed allocation with variable length portions

tema4.question: What is the main drawback of the contiguous allocation mechanism in filesystems?

answers.answer: It is difficult to accommodate changes to the file (i.e., increase size)
The size of the file has to be declared when it is created
All of the above statements are drawbacks of the contiguous allocation mechanism

tema4.question: In a file system that implements chained allocation, which of the following statements is FALSE?

answers.answer: It increases the read and write performance thanks to allowing sequential access
It allows files to grow and shrink easily, since blocks can be added or removed from the chain
It ensures that external fragmentation does not happen
None of the statements is false
